issue vs risk in project management:
The key difference is an “issue” already has occurred and a “risk” is a potential issue that may or may not happen and can impact the project positively or negatively. ... NK Shrivastava, PMI-RMP, PMP: Risk is an event that has not happened yet but may; an issue is something that already has happened.

Selected Answer: D
The scenario described in the question is an example of a functional organizational structure, in which resources are grouped based on their areas of expertise, and the authority for their allocation and management remains with the respective functional manager. In this case, the network coordinator, who is the functional manager for the network security department, has denied the request to allocate the experienced resource to the project. In a functional organizational structure, project managers have little authority to negotiate the terms of resource participation or allocation, as it is the responsibility of the functional manager to ensure the availability and utilization of resources for their department's work.

questions.question_text: A regulatory project is behind schedule, and the project manager informs the steering committee that more resources are needed to complete the automation requirements on time. However, the funding request was rejected. To be in compliance, the project team performs a physical workaround to attempt to complete the project on time. Which of the following is this an example of?

choices.B: The KPIs did not contain the required detail.
choices.C: The RACI matrix was not followed.
choices.A: The SWOT analysis was not performed during planning.
choices.D: The estimated task durations in the WBS were incorrect.

questions.question_text: During the first several months of effort, a project manager reported all metrics at green status. However, during the most recent gate check, many metrics declined to red. Which of the following is the MOST likely reason the project manager was unable to predict the decline?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
This is what I found on the web, and the answer makes sense.
The MOST likely reason the project manager was unable to predict the decline in the project metrics, despite reporting all metrics at green status for several months, is that the estimated task durations in the work breakdown structure (WBS) were incorrect.

The WBS is a hierarchical decomposition of the project into smaller, more manageable components that can be planned, scheduled, and tracked. The estimated task durations in the WBS are an important input into the project schedule and help the project manager to track progress against the baseline plan. If the estimated task durations in the WBS are incorrect, the project manager may not have an accurate view of the project's progress, which can lead to a failure to predict a decline in metrics.
